author: Red_EyedBear
body:
IDK where you're getting this information from, but 5G is going to revolutionize speed and quantity of data transferring. There really won't be anything conventionally available that is faster. Parents work at VZ as regional network directors and have now been a part of the initial building and implementation of 4G and now 5G on the routing side. Shits getting intense with new 5G technology allowing phones to be able to edge-route information transferring instead of all being rerouted back to regional switches. The companies pushing the edge-routing are going to be the stocks to watch (Ericsson, Nokia, Cisco)

Also AI companies are going to be extremely useful in 5G implementation as well.

author: Jas1052
body: I think this is a result of Cisco pummeling Juniper in market share. They also have decreasing revenue yoy by 4%, which is a red flag during a growth period.

author: Ltjenkins
body:
Not sure if you’re joking but I’ll use this to rant a little. Investing is not about buying hype or figuring out how to earn the most over the shortest amount of time. It’s about saving early and often. Your investments should have a good track record and have a reasonable expectation of relatively consistent growth. You shouldn’t be buying just because someone or the internet told you. Most importantly, the early and often investments need to be done over long periods of time. 

There’s no magic sauce to being a millionaire. It just takes a lot longer than what most people want to accept or if you want to do it faster, more risk than most people are willing to take on. If you want to double your money in a year you have to be prepared for it to be down 50% some amount of the time before then.  

CSCO is not a contrarian story to this reasoning. The only reasons it was pushed to its levels in the late 90s were hype and irrationality not the above investment principles. 

Save your money, invest when you can, and buy good solid companies over 30 years and you will be a multimillionaire.

author: option-whisperer
body:
Roll out and up and save on the commission that you would have to pay if you simply closed and reopened. Plus you will be taking in more credit for the new CC for a net gain on the entire thing. This assumes you find a contract that you will get a credit instead of paying a debit. You should never pay to roll. I've done the same thing with my CSCO shares. Had a CC at $48. Rolled out and upped my strike another $2 to $50. Took in more credit and widened my profit target. Gets near $50, rinse and repeat. Edit: I see your CC is ITM by a few strikes. You probably won't find something you can get a credit. Should of rolled sooner. So if you want to keep the stock, that would be your only option.

FYI: selling ATM CC calls isn't the way it should be done... Supposed to be OTM...

author: pkincy
body: You do have an obligation to not underwithhold but at $2200 I would not expect that to be a problem.  However you are going to owe the taxes so reinvesting the $2200 has some extra risk.  What are you going to do if that $2200 goes to zero and the IRS wants their $300?  If coughing it up without any of the $2200 to help is not a problem, OK.  But it would be prudent to take that $300 and put it aside in a savings account so you know you will have it next year.   I will give you an extreme example from exactly 20 years ago.   A Cisco employee has stock option restrictiions come off in early 2000.   Exercises a boat load of options at $75/share.    The boatload was enough to get him to the 39.1% Federal Tax bracket with California state tax another 9% or so.  Doesn't file estimated taxes as he should (isos not nqsos so no withholding necessary) and leaves the money invested in CSCO.   Come early 2001 he has to pony up for his roughly 50% tax on the boatload.  Unfortunately the CSCO stock was at $16/share, so he couldn't afford to pay the tax.   Sad story.    With $2200 earned, and around $300 owed you won't have that problem but you get the idea.

author: psr1029
body:
I agree with buying what you know, but a few of those names are very subjective. Like how much does the average person understand about SpaceX? Even Cisco is somewhat difficult to sum up in a sentence or two. 

I don’t know if it was Lynch or maybe Buffet. But I think it was Lynch who said “If you can’t explain what a company does to a 10 year old in two sentences or less, don’t buy it” something along those lines. Obviously that needs to be taken with a grain of salt, but there’s some truth to it.

author: ernieballer
body: One of the Peter Lynch (and many other's philosophies) is to buy what you know.  That is publicly traded services/products that you are directly in touch with and have faith in.  For me I use Microsoft Outlook, that's 1, before that our company used Gmail, that's 2, we're also a CISCO vendor, that's 3, I used to drink Coca Cola, that's 4. I used to shop at Walmart (not in the US anymore), that's 5.  I have an iPhone and bought the original iPod (even as a Microsoft die-hard), that's 6.  I haven't back-tested this portfolio but I imagine it would have crushed it.  This strategy;  realization of brand value should not be overlooked and will probably never become outdated.  I'm also weirdly excited by Elon Musk and love SpaceX.  If I was a millionaire I'd probably buy a Tesla, because fuck it. That's 7. This strategy would have more than likely done well. Companies with high service/product reviews may have a bit of a moat, that could equate to earnings growth. I'm personally a fan of his prior work and investment philosophy.

The Dow is more so an industrial ETF. Contains companies like CAT, Cisco, Visa, Intel, Home Depot. Only 30 stocks so I think it’s safe to say it’s volatile. 

S&P500 is the top 500 publicly traded companies in the US. 

Nasdaq is 100 US Stocks that exclude the financial sector. Very tech heavy.

author: mfrumen
body:
CSCO has been beaten down since last ER I believe due to lower guidance. I think they are a good value because of their consistent buybacks and how well positioned they are to benefit from the ever increasing importance if cybersecurity. Yields close to 3% too. 

AOS is susceptible to the trade talks so the worst may be over for them. Or not. Either way a solid company with a solid, fast growing dividend. 

CHRW took a beating last ER due to lower than expected earnings and lower earnings forecasted for the near future. Personally I think the continued rise of ecommerce will lessen the decrease in earnings they expect but I have not done too much DD on this one.

author: Throwthler1
body:
Funny these two companies are paired together. 

TRST had their licences to produce revoked. Is under the microscope of federal regulators. They are currently forced to provide a status update in accordance with its obligations under the alternative information guidelines set out in National Policy 12-203 – Management Cease Trade Orders ("NP 12-203"), which require the Company to provide bi-weekly updates until such time as the Company is current with its filing obligations under Canadian securities laws.

ACB is the #2 biggest cannabis company in the world. With operations in 25 countries. The biggest medical cannabis supplier in Canada. Has over 20% of the Canadian market overall. Was the first LP to have edibles available to the market on December 18th and are continual selling out of product, faster than it hits the shelves. Yup, they have debt, much like every other cannabis company. They have a potential large amount of goodwill that might be written down, maybe, at some point in the future, depending on the performance of their acquisitions over the next few years. I'm betting the accounting department does some financial gymnastics here and finds a optimistic outcome. Then comes the share dilution. Aurora bought a bunch of companies using dilution of over 1 billion shares... That's a lot of shares. Whenever a company issues shares at a price higher than the shares' intrinsic value -- whether it does so to buy another company or to sell the shares and raise cash on the market -- an outside shareholder benefits, despite his or her percentage of ownership being diluted. This is exactly what Aurora did. Aurora was over valued for quite a long time and they took advantage of that situation by throwing the weight of their stock around. During the 90s pretty much every acquisition you saw by Microsoft or Cisco was paid for in richy valued stock. None of this points to them soon going out of business very soon.

author: meoraine
body: I worked cyber engineering for the DoD for 6 years. In that time I worked a bunch of different programs with a bunch of different agencies. Keep in mind, the DoD develops quite a lot of its cyber tools through contractors and these products are often classified without being known to the general public. However, as far as COTS & Off The Shelf cyber hardware/software goes, they are still heavily Cisco based. I've seen Owl Cyber Defense used quite a lot for their diodes. Fortify deployed nearly everywhere. And Nessus as a DoD requirement, again, deployed nearly everywhere. McAfee for endpoint. In my experience, these companies are the dominant players in this space and a lot of the newer names are still vying to be the future replacements for much of this older tech. As far as defense contractors and which companies are winning cyber bids, I saw a lot of ManTech towards the end of my tenure. BAH, Lockheed, ASRC, Raytheon.

Looking to add another $15k in by mid-spring, diversify properly and distribute it between AMZN, MSFT, AAPL, BRK.A and KO. Telsa was my biggest gamble probably. Currently, it's not very well balanced and can go to shit if my TSLA stock tanks basically.

If it wasn't for the overly complicated/stupid taxes around index funds/ETFs where I live then I would have probably just owned a ton of S&P 500 and a few blue chips. I use my stockbroker as a secondary savings account essentially.

author: WikiTextBot
body:
**Dot-com bubble**

The dot-com bubble (also known as the dot-com boom, the tech bubble, and the Internet bubble) was a historic period of excessive speculation mainly in the United States that occurred roughly from 1994 to 2000, a period of massive growth in the use, and adoption of the Internet.The Nasdaq Composite stock market index, which included many Internet-based companies, peaked in value on March 10, 2000, before crashing. The burst of the bubble, known as the dot-com crash, lasted from March 11, 2000, to October 9, 2002. During the crash, many online shopping companies, such as Pets.com, Webvan, and Boo.com, as well as communication companies, such as Worldcom, NorthPoint Communications and Global Crossing, failed and shut down. Others, such as Cisco, whose stock declined by 86%, and Qualcomm, lost a big portion of their market capitalization but survived, and some companies, such as eBay and Amazon.com, lost value but recovered quickly.

***

author: omgroki
body: When my options drop to sub $0.10, I usually throw another $20 at it. More often than not, I get a chance to exit the DCA at +100% and feel better. Did this with $CSCO recently. Bought 2 @ $1.05. Bought 4 more at $0.05. Sold all 6 at $0.13.

author: pkincy
body: In the stock market it is never too late if you have a long enough time horizon.   Take Csco.  Great tech company.   In early 2000 it was $77.31/sh.  Today it is $49.02.   Likely within another 10 years it will return or exceed the $77.31 mark.  So those that bought in 2000 will break even by 2030 pretty likely.
